channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Palestinians Clash With Own Security Forces as Elections Stir Deep Unease
item.media:description: Members of the Palestinian security forces patrolled the West Bank city of Nablus last month.
item.description: Internal divisions are tearing at Palestinian society, leading to a wave of unrest in the West Bank marked by deaths and a raucous funeral procession.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Kurds Fear the U.S. Will Again Betray Them, in Syria
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters near Qamishli, Syria, last year. The Syrian Kurds say their aim is to establish an autonomous region, not their own state, where their rights are protected, in whatever settlement comes from the long Syrian civil war.
item.description: Throughout history, Washington and other Western powers have used the Kurds for their ends, then abandoned them when it became expedient.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Merkel Feels Political Pressure in Germany as Europe Is in Flux
item.media:description: The party of the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, is being challenged by the far-right Alternative for Germany.
item.description: Her open door for refugees has led to a strong electoral challenge from the far right at home and is complicating her efforts to forge a response to Britain’s decision to leave the E.U.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Christiania, a Commune in Denmark, Dismantles Drug Market After Shootings
item.media:description: Residents destroyed drug vendors’ stalls in the Christiania neighborhood of Copenhagen on Friday.
item.description: The decision to demolish the market in the Christiania neighborhood of Copenhagen came after a suspected drug dealer shot and wounded two police officers and a bystander.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Islam Karimov Dies at 78, Ending a Long, Ruthless Rule of Uzbekistan
item.media:description: Mr. Karimov after greeting Secretary of State John Kerry at Samarkand Airport in Uzbekistan on Nov. 1, 2015. Mr. Kerry was visiting five Central Asian nations.
item.description: Mr. Karimov’s nearly three-decade reign was often described as one of the most brutal to emerge after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Rome Journal: With Mother Teresa Set to Be Canonized, Her Work Lives On in the Streets
item.media:description: Sisters of the Missionaries of Charity, the religious congregation founded by Mother Teresa in 1950, receiving communion during Mass at a motherhouse in Rome last week.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Her Missionaries of Charity religious congregation has continued to grow, serving the poor around the world, and just outside the seat of the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Indonesia Is Pushed to Ban Alcohol for Health of Bodies, if Not Souls
item.media:description: Customers enjoying the drinks and the view at a bar in Jakarta, which has hundreds of upscale hotels, restaurants and pubs that serve alcohol.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Islamist parties long opposed to drinking have taken a new line: that alcohol should be banned for health reasons, rather than religious ones.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Deadly Explosion Hits Night Market in Davao City, Philippines
item.description: The cause of explosion, which killed at least 12 people in President Rodrigo Duterte’s hometown, was unknown, but the blast followed death threats against the leader.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: No Zika Cases Reported During Rio Olympics, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The World Health Organization said data from Brazil had convinced its experts that no infections had occurred either during the Games or after visitors and athletes had gone home.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Thousands March in Venezuela to Demand President’s Ouster
item.media:description: Thousands of Venezuelans marched in Caracas, the capital, on Thursday to express their anger over the country’s economic collapse and the government’s leadership.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Opponents of President Nicolás Maduro took to the streets of Caracas to protest the nation’s economic collapse and its government.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and PATRICIA TORRES

item.title: African Elephant Population Dropped 30 Percent in 7 Years
item.media:description: An African elephant at the Mpala Research Center and Wildlife Foundation in Kenya.
item.description: The decline is accelerating: Largely because of poaching, the African elephant population is dropping 8 percent a year.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Violence After Gabon Elections Leaves One Dead
item.media:description: Police officers in Gabon on patrol near the National Assembly in Libreville, the capital, on Thursday.
item.description: Security forces in the West African nation clashed with opposition supporters after the declaration of a second term for President Ali Bongo Ondimba.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Ireland to Appeal Tax Ruling in Apple Case
item.media:description: Apple’s offices in Cork, Ireland, where it employs over 5,000 people.
item.description: The country’s cabinet unanimously agreed to fight the $14.5 billion decision, and politicians are expected to debate it next week.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Battling Drug-Resistant TB, and the Indian Government
item.media:description: Dr. Zarir Udwadia has criticized India’s government for failing to take advantage of a new generation of medicines to stamp out tuberculosis.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.description: Dr. Zarir Udwadia shocked the world and fought with New Delhi after identifying an untreatable form of tuberculosis. Now he’s a sought-after international expert.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Trapped in Homs, Architect Imagines a New Future for Syrian Cities
item.media:description: A sketch by Marwa al-Sabouni of possible future housing that echoes traditional architecture.
item.description: In a book and Ted talk, Marwa al-Sabouni calls for a return to traditional styles, saying that recent construction has only fueled sectarian tensions.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN HEYMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: For China’s Children, a Resoundingly Patriotic Return to School
item.media:description: Pupils at the Yusha Experimental School in Haikou, Hainan Province, saluting China’s flag on the first day of school. Schoolchildren are being urged this year to emulate the spirit of the Red Army on the Long March.
item.description: The Education Ministry required that students watch a television show extolling the spirit of the Communist Red Army as it escaped its enemies on the Long March.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Pakistan Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 11 at Court Compound
item.description: The assault at a district court in the city of Mardan was the second mass attack in recent weeks that appeared to target lawyers.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: ‘The Way People Look at Us Has Changed’: Muslim Women on Life in Europe
item.media:description: Saima Ashraf, 39, at the Barking Town Hall in London, where she is a leader in the local government. She said such an achievement would not have been possible for her as a veiled woman in her home country, France.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: An outpouring from Times readers described their daily experiences in parts of Europe that are most tense because of recent terror attacks.
item.dc:creator: LILLIE DREMEAUX

item.title: Peru Sentences Ex-Soldiers to Prison for Killing Villagers in 1985
item.description: The were killed in the village of Accomarca during the height of a conflict between the government and Shining Path rebels.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Obama Visits Midway, Highlighting Monument and Commitment to Environment
item.media:description: President Obama boarded Air Force One on Thursday on his way to the newly expanded Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument.
item.description: The president, an eye on his legacy, recognized the expansion of the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument in the remote reaches of the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: T.P.P. Faces Rough Road in Congress
item.media:description: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, greeted President Obama in May. Vietnam is among 12 nations to sign the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.description: Democrats and Republicans are finding the politics of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord so risky that its prospects are uncertain.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Sinosphere: Behind China’s Anbang: Empty Offices and Obscure Names
item.media:description: The fourth floor of a building in Beijing houses two companies that control assets of Anbang Insurance Group worth more than $15 billion.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The Chinese insurer has made a global splash with its deals, but its ownership lacks the marquee investors that a major company typically boasts.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: A Chinese Mystery: Who Owns a Firm on a Global Shopping Spree?
item.description: Owners of Anbang, a Chinese insurer behind a wave of multibillion-dollar deals, include relatives and friends of its politically connected chairman.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and JONATHAN ANSFIELD

item.title: Gun Battle Between Ethnic Factions Roils Afghanistan’s Capital
item.media:description: Carrying the coffin of Habibullah Kalakani, who briefly seized the Afghan throne in 1929, during a reburial ceremony at the Eid Gah Mosque in Kabul.
item.description: At least one fighter was killed when Uzbek militiamen loyal to the vice president clashed with Tajik demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Israel Courts Foreign Money in Effort to Become Gas Exporter
item.media:description: A worker from the Israeli Tamar gas platform and the Mari-B platform in the eastern Mediterranean Sea off Israel. The Tamar field now supplies the fuel for a sizable portion of Israeli electricity production.
item.description: The campaign is a major shift for a country whose government wrestled with how to regulate the energy industry.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: Memo from Jerusalem: As Trump vs. Clinton Captivates World, Netanyahu Is Unusually Silent
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, second from left, led a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Tuesday.
item.description: Four years after he was accused of meddling in the American election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is being careful not to take sides.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of Turkish History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Fatal Beating of Polish Man Fuels Debate Over Xenophobia in Britain
item.media:description: A vigil for Arkadiusz Jozwik, who died from injuries sustained during an attack in Harlow, England.
item.media:credit: Chris Radburn/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: As the police investigate whether the killing of Arkadiusz Jozwik, 40, was motivated by hate, Poland’s ambassador expressed alarm.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Refugees’ Lives ‘Stripped of Meaning’ by Detention, Australian Author Says
item.media:description: A protest in Sydney, Australia, last week over the country’s offshore detention policy for asylum seekers and refugees.
item.media:credit: Hugh Peterswald/Pacific Press/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: Richard Flanagan described the suffering by refugees and asylum seekers held on the islands of Nauru and Manus as so extreme that it has been compared to torture.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s ‘Core Socialist Values,’ the Song-and-Dance Version
item.description: In Hunan Province, the authorities have come up with 20 “square dance” routines to extol qualities like patriotism, dedication and equality.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Hong Kong Independence Movement Contests Beijing at the Polls
item.media:description: Sixtus Leung, known as Baggio, is running for Legislative Council as a member of the Youngspiration party. He is part of a new, youthful force in Hong Kong that is on the cusp of acquiring a measure of actual power.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: A new, youthful force, supporting some degree of greater self-determination for Hong Kong, may acquire a small measure of actual power in the election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Bags of Cocaine Worth $56 Million Are Found at Coca-Cola Factory in France
item.media:description: Bottles of Coca-Cola on an assembly line at a factory near Paris.
item.description: The cocaine amounted to 370 kilograms and was stowed in a shipment of orange juice concentrate to the plant in the town of Signes.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: With Impeachment Over, Brazil’s Next Challenge Is Its Flailing Economy
item.description: The new president, Michel Temer, must navigate his own controversies and a quarrelsome Congress to lead Latin America’s largest nation out of a deepening fiscal crisis.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Report Finds Ban Hasn’t Halted Use of Cluster Bombs in Syria or Yemen
item.media:description: Yemenis at a protest in January outside the United Nations offices in Sana, the capital, shouted anti-Saudi slogans and carried the remains of a cluster bomb believed to have been dropped in Saudi-led airstrikes.
item.description: Most of the world’s countries have signed a treaty banning the munitions, but not the United States and Russia, where many such bombs were made.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Tim Cook, Apple Chief, Defends Tax Practices and Says Cash Will Return to U.S.
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s competition commissioner, said Apple’s sweetheart deals with the Irish government allowed the company to sidestep taxes.
item.description: The company’s chief executive said in an interview with an Irish broadcaster that the European Union’s tax decision was “maddening” and politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, Former Israeli Defense Minister, Dies at 80
item.media:description: Benjamin Ben-Eliezer in 2002.
item.description: Mr. Ben-Eliezer, who was born in Iraq, served in the military for 30 years, held senior positions in government and was close to Arab leaders.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Remembering Alan Kurdi: Syrian Family’s Tragedy Goes Beyond Image of Boy on Beach
item.media:description: Hivrun Kurdi, an aunt of Alan's, with her children in a refugee shelter in Bramsche, Germany, this month. Weeks after Alan drowned, Hivrun and her children made the same perilous sea journey from Turkey to Greece.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The death of Alan Kurdi, 2, which focused the world on refugees, was just one chapter of a sprawling family’s story in its desperate attempts to escape Syria and find a new home.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: What in the World: Malta’s Walls Are Covered in Murals, and Street Art Is Covered in Schools
item.media:description: A man relaxed last week near a mural under an overhanging footpath along the coast in Sliema, Malta.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Most cities denounce, or tolerate, painting on public property. But on this Mediterranean island, the process is not only encouraged, it is funded.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GRIFFITHS

item.title: What in the World: How Some Chinese Men Meet Summer’s Swelter: With Midriff Bare and Bulging
item.media:description: A man near Beijing’s Forbidden City this month rolled up his shirt, a way to keep cool known as the Beijing bikini.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Nothing defines China’s hottest days more than the Beijing Bikini: grown men, without a hint of shame, rolling up shirts to expose often generous bellies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Secrets and Suspicion in Uzbekistan
item.description: Uzbeks have never known their country without their longtime dictator, Islam Karimov.
item.dc:creator: SARAH KENDZIOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Dismal Days for Brazilian Democracy
item.media:description: Dilma Rousseff at her impeachment trial in Brazil.
item.description: Unpopular as Dilma Rousseff’s presidency was, the irony of her ouster is that she was one of the few politicians untainted by corruption.
item.dc:creator: JULIANA BARBASSA

item.title: Editorial: Gridlock in Spain
item.description: A coalition with hostile factions hardly promises effective governance, but a messy government is better than none at all.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
